newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Serbian economy in decline after Balkan turmoil.
newsitem.headline: Serbian economy in decline after Balkan turmoil.

text.p: The sprawling IMT tractor factory in Yugoslavia once produced 40,000 tractors a year and exported to more than 100 countries. Now it makes at best 4,000 and sells mainly to former Yugoslav republics .
"I won't go into all the details, but because of everything that happened we are now producing at less than 10 percent of capacity," said acting manager Vidan Dokovic.

The "everything that happened" in Yugoslavia included the bloody breakup of the federal republic, international sanctions imposed from 1992 to 1996 and a standoff, now in its third month, between Serbia's Socialist President Slobodan Milosevic and the opposition Zajedno (Together) coalition over annulment of Zajedno victories in November municipal elections.
The standoff has brought stern warnings from the West and veiled hints that sanctions could be employed again if Milosevic does not give way.

"One of the saddest things for a manager is to see the machinery and hear everything quiet," Dokovic said as he led a reporter on a tour of his plant, deserted after the one shift by 4,000 workers of what used to be a 6,500-man work force.
"You don't know how many millions of dollars of machinery are just sitting there, doing nothing," he said.
Economists say the problems in Yugoslavia, now comprising Serbia and tiny Montenegro, run deeper than anything caused by wars, sanctions or the political impasse.

"Our economy is in deep crisis and there are so many problems," said Aleksandra Posarac, economist at the Institute of Economic Sciences and an adviser to Vesna Pesic, head of the Civic Alliance party and a Zajedno co-leader.
"Industry is working at 40 percent (of capacity) ... and many branches work at 10 percent," she said, adding that per capita income had plunged from $3,000 in 1990 to about $1,500.
The government says 2.1 million people are employed, but independent institutes put the number at 700,000 to 800,000.
Strikes are frequent, those who are working often are paid less than full wages, and some factories skip paychecks, among them IMT, which missed four of 12 months last year.
"The problems were all there before the sanctions, but when the sanctions were imposed, the immediate effect in three months was a 30 percent drop in industrial production," Posarac said.
"It made all foreign trade illegal, more or less, so we were selling cheap and buying dear."

It amounts to a huge comedown for Yugoslavia, which as a communist but non-aligned nation under the late Marshal Tito, had perhaps the most liberal economy in Eastern Europe and granted state enterprises a fair amount of autonomy.
Yugo cars produced by Zastava were sold in the United States, which also bought tractors from IMT, once the biggest tractor producer in Eastern Europe outside the former Soviet Union.

While other former Communist bloc countries such as Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia adopted free-market reforms when communism collapsed, Serbia stuck to a mixed socialist economy under Milosevic, and went into decline.
The Serbian government has issued statements saying it intends to privatise government-owned businesses, but so far has done little, economists say, although Montenegro has gone ahead with reforms.

"You cannot privatise overnight, you cannot restructure in a year. This process will probably take at least five or 10 years, but we need to start as soon as possible," said Zoran Popov, an economist at the Economics Institute, which is considered to have close links to the government.
"But you see, if the government or the party is to prepare a decent and honest privatisation and restructuring programme I think it would be suicide for this party," Popov said.
"You have to tell, say, 400,000 people employed in the metals sector that for half of them there are no prospects."
Economists said many company directors are ministers or high-level Socialists who owe their jobs to party patronage.
Dokovic, who has been acting manager at IMT for only a month, said he is trying to strike deals with foreign buyers.
"This is not a question of politics. What I am interested in is the factory itself and the 4,000 people who work in it."
Posarac and other economists think that Yugoslavia's industry-oriented economy has largely been outstripped by competitors. A massive readjustment is in order.
"Who's going to buy these tractors?" she asked. "The peasants haven't got the money and I really don't know about exports because there are cheaper and better tractors around."
